b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:00): notes that requiring spaces between a quoted attribute value and the next attribute name will make valid HTML4 invalid.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:02): that's true
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:02): would estimate that to be about zero HTML4 documents in practice
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:04): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: how about any HTML documents (not just counting valid HTML4)?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:04): I still estimate about zero
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:04): based on no data, except I don't remember ever seeing people intentionally omit spaces between attributes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:05): (so my view doesn't really count)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:05): i don't either, but i have seen it in some text/html-XHTML documents (so it was not intentional)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:05): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: actually, when the W3C Validator fixed this for XHTML, there were (angry) people who found their previously 'valid' pages were in fact invalid
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:06): would be interesting to see if pages that lack spaces between attributes do so because of mismatching quotes or not
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:07): (since that's what the new requirement is supposed to help with)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:07): Oh, maybe it's more common that I expected
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:08): I see /<[a-z]+ [a-z]+="([^"]+)"[a-z]/ on about ...
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:08): also, perhaps the other new requirements are sufficient for catching mismatched quotes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:08): Hixie: any particular reason why < didn't become invalid in unquoted attribute values along =, ' and ?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:08): waits for it to continue finding matches
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:09): ... lots of pages
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:10): About 5K (out of 130K), plus lots of margin of error
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:11): though it looks like a lot of them are from the same site
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:11): (which says <d
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:11): iv id="gb_city/cottonwood-az_5"class="act_gbar" style="left: 25px; height: 18px" ></div>)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:11): (...without the line wrapping)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:13): i guess the whitespace between attributes requirement has a high noise to signal ratio
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:13): <font face="arial color="silver">X - Y - </font>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:14): quote in attribute name would catch that one
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:14): is the only error I've found after seeing about a dozen that are simply skipping the space
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:15): <img src="http://www.w3.org/Icons/valid-xhtml10"alt="Valid XHTML 1.0!" height="31" width="88" /> - hmm
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:17): goes away for a while
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:18): i can't come up with a case where requiring whitespace between attributes helps to catch mistakes that quotes in attribute names don't
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:20): unless *two* quotes were omitted, e.g. <input value="foo disabled="disabled>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:20): but that's very unlikely
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:20): I am not opposed to making it an error, fwiw. (at least not yet)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:21): if it doesn't catch any harmful mistakes, isn't it just adding noise to the list of validation messages?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:22): that's a possibility
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:23): though this way the tokenizer spec comes closer to be hackable into an XML5 tokenizer that reports XML 1.0 4th ed. errors non-fatally
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:25): every time I patch ?Ülfred2 I come closer to biting the bullet and turning the Validator.nu HTML parser into a non-Draconian XML parser as well.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:25): if it weren't for DTDs (internal subset in particular), I'd be hacking on that right now
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:26): there are more html authors that validate their documents than there are non-drocanian xml tokenizer implementors
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:35): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: even among feed readers?
